title: Was Plato originally called Aristocles? - Quora

response.answer_text: According to the third-century AD Greek biographer Diogenes Laërtios in his book Lives and Opinions of Eminent Philosophers, Plato’s original name was Ἀριστοκλῆς (Aristoklês), after his grandfather. Supposedly, the name Plato (Πλάτων in Greek) was given to him by his wrestling coach Ariston of Argos as a nickname on account of his “broad” shoulders, or perhaps his “broad” forehead, since the Greek word meaning “broad” is πλατύς (platýs). Later writers claimed that he had received the nickname due to the breadth of his thought. Modern historians are unsure of whether or not to take Diogenes Laërtios’s account at face value, since he was writing centuries after Plato’s death and all of the manuscripts of Plato’s dialogues clearly give their author’s name as “Plato,” not “Aristokles.” Plato was a common name in Athens at the time when Plato was alive. In fact, there were at least thirty-one other men named Plato in Athens from around the same time period, so it was not necessarily a nickname or, if it was a nickname, it was apparently a very common one. Nonetheless, there are no records of Plato having had any relatives with this name and it was traditional for sons to be named after their paternal grandfathers. For my own part, I rather suspect that the story may be accurate, since it does not really seem like the sort of thing biographers would be inclined to make up and it is widely reported in the biographical sources, late though they are. In any case, though, certainly by the time he started writing dialogues, Plato was only known by one name: Plato.
